30 Dec 2023

2024 needs patience and assertiveness (for me)

Filed under: life

I almost didn‚Äôt write this, but my friend Dom Griffin made a video where he explained that sometimes, you just gotta do the work even when you don‚Äôt want to. So here I am.

I wrote an article called 2017 Needs Brevity And Nuance 7 years ago and while I still think we need both, I want something else in 2024‚Äîand mainly for me.

2023 has shown me how impatient we can all be and I‚Äôve definitely felt that thrown in my direction this year. It has caused me stress, anxiety, and exhausted me beyond belief. Sometimes, it was an urgent need for my time or expertise where panic was unwarranted. Or where I struggled with something and needed someone to be patient with me, but got the opposite. With my ongoing journey through autism and neurodivergence as a whole, I‚Äôve noticed things I do that people can find difficult to deal with: mainly how I communicate and my issues with decisiveness. I‚Äôm not trying to be weird or make things hard for people; my brain just gets in the way of the best or simplest solution. But while I navigate that, I need people to give me time and space to get there rather than feel like I‚Äôm an inconvenience, being weird, or acting like a child. In hindsight, my neurodivergence has been around for decades and I‚Äôve had to learn how neurotypical people act and respond accordingly. So I‚Äôm not a weird kid‚ÄîI‚Äôm an adult who just needs some patience to get to where we all want to go. It‚Äôs the least I deserve, especially when I actively give that time and space to other people.

And that‚Äôs where the need for assertiveness comes in. I went to my first CBT sessions back in 2017 (it was a pivotal year, evidently!) and assertiveness was something that cropped up a lot as something I needed. Elements of it have improved, particularly in work, but I could still do a lot better. In fact, I‚Äôve arguably regressed in certain areas of my life; backing down rather than saying something. I say it‚Äôs to conserve energy and while that‚Äôs true, there may have been times where I could have dealt with issues better if I‚Äôd been assertive rather than passive (or aggressive, another annoying go-to of mine). It‚Äôs easier said than done but setting boundaries, being firm in them, and not backing down‚Äîeven if there are uncomfortable conversations and reactions involved‚Äîis ultimately for the best.

Ultimately, I know people see me in a certain way and I have no intention of changing the things that they see. But knowing people treat me differently because of them, in a way I can see and feel, makes me sad. It‚Äôs not about wanting to be normal or ‚Äúnot me‚Äù (been there, done that), it‚Äôs about a wish for patience from others and for people to maybe stop and think about how they act and the impacts those actions have. Wherever we are on the everchanging planes of neurodivergence, we could also use a bit of care and time to ponder and reflect and make life a bit easier to deal with. I want that for me and if that can‚Äôt be the default, I‚Äôll firmly prod you with my assertiveness rod until I get it.

But no worries if not, let me know xxx
